steps.title: Use your owner's manual to locate the exhaust manifold.
steps.content: Use your owner's manual to locate the exhaust manifold. 4-cylinder engines have one exhaust manifold. 6 or 8-cylinder vehicles have two manifolds. Look for the manifold in front of the engine block on a front-end driven vehicle. Find the manifold on the side of the engine block on a rear-driven. This may vary slightly on boat engines or those on other small vehicles.

steps.title: Familiarize yourself with your manifold's design.
steps.content: Familiarize yourself with your manifold's design. [1] X Research source Most exhaust manifolds are made of cast iron or a steel alloy similarly able to handle high temperatures. Each manifold has an exhaust port matched to each exhaust outlet on the cylinder head. The exhaust flows through these ports to a single outlet. These ports are openings in an otherwise flat machined surface that fits with a gasket to the surface of the cylinder head. Gaskets, made of paper, asbestos materials, or copper, serve as seals to prevent leakage between the manifold and cylinder head.

steps.title: Wear safety equipment, including gloves, dust mask, and goggles.
steps.content: Wear safety equipment, including gloves, dust mask, and goggles.

steps.title: Allow the engine to cool completely for 30 to 60 minutes.
steps.content: Allow the engine to cool completely for 30 to 60 minutes.

steps.title: Remove all the hoses that are attached to the manifold.
steps.content: Remove all the hoses that are attached to the manifold. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Spray the bolts on the manifold heat shield (usually found on recent cars) with lubricating solvent and remove with socket wrench.
steps.content: Spray the bolts on the manifold heat shield (usually found on recent cars) with lubricating solvent and remove with socket wrench.

steps.title: Remove all bolts on the manifold itself after applying lubricating spray solvent.
steps.content: Remove all bolts on the manifold itself after applying lubricating spray solvent.

steps.title: Remove the manifold in a well ventilated work space.
steps.content: Remove the manifold in a well ventilated work space.

steps.title: Coat the interior of the manifold with lacquer thinner.
steps.content: Coat the interior of the manifold with lacquer thinner.

steps.title: Scrub coated areas with wire brush and steel wool.
steps.content: Scrub coated areas with wire brush and steel wool.

steps.title: Use electric grinder to break up debris.
steps.content: Use electric grinder to break up debris.

steps.title: Repeat the process throughout until you are satisfied with the look of the metal.
steps.content: Repeat the process throughout until you are satisfied with the look of the metal. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe the manifold clean throughout with lacquer thinner.
steps.content: Wipe the manifold clean throughout with lacquer thinner. Lacquer thinner is a solvent, but it also cures the metal with a coating that you can thicken with repeated applications.

steps.title: Match the ports to those on the cylinder head, and replace gasket before bolting manifold in place.
steps.content: Match the ports to those on the cylinder head, and replace gasket before bolting manifold in place. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Contact your local dealer or research repairs in order to determine the precise sequence and torque level to follow when reinstalling the manifold.
steps.content: Contact your local dealer or research repairs in order to determine the precise sequence and torque level to follow when reinstalling the manifold.
